> > With regards to self-organization when building NN's there is
> another
> > major problem and that is how to instill the network with
> functionality.
> > With direct encoding the genome describes the functionality by
> > describing the neurons, connections and connection weights
> directly.
> > With self-organization I don't see this being possible, in biology
> AFAIK
> > the resulting network provides a basic framework of connections
> that
> > support reinforcement learning - and that learning is how
> functionality
> > finds it's way into the network. This is a major shift from the NE
> > techniques I have seen to date.
> >
>
> This is a very interesting issue. I am not sure though whether
> functionality cannot be encoded in a self-organizing system. It's a
> really good question. Does anyone have thoughts on this? It seems
> that a self-organizing system that produces repeating patterns can
> encapsulate functionality within those patterns, although this might
> be more difficult than having it learn the functionality through
> further experience.


Yes, if I rememeber correctly an example of repeated basic functionality 
can be found in the human retina. The input from red, green and blue 
receptors (cones) is adjusted by a simple hard wired neural net within 
the retina. So say a mutation occurs that makes a larger retina with 
more cone cells, you would see them all wired up the same. But when it 
comes to the more complex functionailty, say,  in the visual cortex, 
then the neural structures there are probably more like a blank canvas 
and the ability to actualy interpret images is learned. Perhaps there is 
some high level structure that corresponds to the different stages of 
image interpretation - line detection followed by object detection, etc. 
and this high level structure aids the type of learning that occurs in 
that part of the brain.

>
> Paradoxically, learning itself is a functionality which requires
> some kind of initial pattern (perhaps a pattenr of learning rules),
> but it may be a simpler initial pattern, and so easier to self-
> organize. There has been a fair amount of work on evolving adaptive
> neural networks that can adapt their functionality during their
> lifetime. For example, see our paper, "Evolving Adaptive Neural
> Networks with and without Adaptive Synapses":

I actually know very little about adaptive networks and what the current 
state of research in this area. I'll certainly read the paper as a starter.


> Anyway, ultimately there may be an important union between adaptive
> neuroevolution and self-organization in indirect encoding.

Certainly that's where I would like to see NE research shifting towards. 
All of a sudden I feel like I don't know much about either area. :)

Colin
